comments:
When I'm doing any action in eclipse (especially opening a source file) it
starts to eat up all the available CPU. Scrollbar sliders nor menus are
reacting. Waiting several minutes doesn't show any effect. But if I am selecting
the project root in  
the browsing view the CPU usage returns normal until the next action. 
I tested the behaviour on 2.0-gtk 2.1 M4-gtk and 2.1 M5-gtk. (i didn't test any
other versions) 2.1 M5 motif is working. 
All I changed on my sytem was an minor update to gtk. I am using debian
linux(i386) with libgtk version 2.2.1-1. My JDK is Sun 1.4.1_01. libc is 2.3.1-9.
And I had a working 2.1 M4-gtk before and I don't have any problems with other
gtk apps.
Are there entries in the .metadata/.log file?

Alright. I am a debian beginner. I hope somebody will give you better advise
than I can, but to not letting you wait, here are my steps (all to be executed
as root)
a) Install Debian woody
b) run apt-setup and select a network source
c) go to /etc/apt/sources.list and replace the word "stable" with "unstable",
but for the last entry (security is only available in testing and stable).
c) as root execute apt-get update && apt-get dist-upgrade.
This will download and upgrade your system to the current "unstable" version of
debian.
d) apt-get install gtk2.0-examples 
This should install everything needed for eclipse/gtk2. 

Don't have Debian handy at the moment, so some of the details might be slightly
inacurate.

Furthermore I installed sun's JDK 1.4.1_01 and eclipse m5/gtk2 by hand.

I believe that would be all to reproduce the bug.
I am also using KDE3.1 and gnome2. Not sure if that might be part of the problem
too.

Hope that helps,
Mariano

Btw. Unstable means that the packaging isn't tested thoroughly, it doesn't mean
that the package content is unstable.
